title: Thursday, 2nd November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

Suppose we should have this chap as our pic for today

PM11:01am

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Jerome Powell

PM11:02am

It it a thing that central bankers need to be suave now?

PM11:03am

Also, it's rates going up day in the UK

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Can't forget that

PM11:03am

In fact, we're something of a warm up act

PM11:03am

For this https://www.youtub...394de8a3-111054549

11:03 am
PM11:04am

PM11:04am

PM11:04am

11:04 am
BE11:05am

And in the meantime, an alternative picture to a guy in a suit.

BE11:05am

https://twitter.com/sarahoconnor_/status/926019783446933504

PM11:05am

And also some video from FX shops, offering you broker services in Cyprus.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

I'm sure they are all legit

BE11:05am

Yes, I'm sure they're safe custodians of your money at 500-1 leverage.

PM11:06am

Excellent cake btw

11:06 am
BE11:06am

(@Flaneur: captcha? Are you arriving through a proxy?)

BE11:07am

What can we say about the impending (80% probability) hike that hasn't been said already?

BE11:07am

Not much, I guess.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Nothing

BE11:07am

Thumbs up

PM11:07am

Here's a preview tho

11:07 am
PM11:07am

https://www.ft.com...-b8a3-38a6e068f464

undefined
PM11:08am

Actually, do you want some grey on Powell?

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Not even slightly, but someone on the right could.

PM11:08am

hehe

PM11:09am

We expect continuity in policy from a Powell FedGovernor Powell has been a member of the Board of Governors since 2012. He has not dissented on policy, and his views have been uniformly in line with the center of the FOMC. Our baseline view of a hike in December and two more next year is reaffirmed with this news.He's not an economist, but he could beAlthough Powell is not a trained economist, he has developed a deep understanding of macroeconomics and monetary policy. He is well liked and well respected on the Committee and understands the processes of the FOMC, as well. That combination means that he should be able to create consensus within the Committee fairly easily.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

What about supervision and regulation?Powell has already spoken on regulation in his current role. His views, consistent with the current Fed Board, is that the broad strokes of post-Crisis regulation are appropriate but that some re-calibration of the existing regulation is likely in order. We do not think that there will be a wholesale roll back of regulation. Rather, we anticipate a measured adjustment, starting with the stress tests and possibly adjustments to the leverage ratio. A change in regulation there could have market implications, but the timeline likely remains somewhat distant; as we have said, we do not expect a material change before late next year.

PM11:09am

That will do

PM11:09am

Cardiff's threatening a post when the news is formally confirmed

11:09 am
PM11:10am

Rabble -- you should know that we're losing Cardiff.

PM11:10am

He's off to be a radio star

PM11:10am

Which is sad for us

11:10 am
PM11:10am

But I'm sure he'll be great at NPR

undefined
BE11:11am

Okay, so few bits of corporate around.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Several from the ..... warmer ..... side of the gambling industry.

PM11:11am

Indeed

BE11:11am

@FJP has mentioned Playtech's warning.....

11:11 am
Playtech PLC (PTEC:LSE): Last: 778.00, down 208.5 (-21.14%), High: 830.00, Low: 737.00, Volume: 7.12m
BE11:12am

Where the mention of Sun Bingo has attracted most of the headlines, though I respectfully suggest this might be a McGuffin.

BE11:13am

Because ....... well, actually, let's reverse. What even is Playtech?

11:13 am
PM11:13am

Statement here https://www.invest...1711020700053626V/

BE11:13am

One answer is, "it's a company that provides the software and stuff for casino websites for Chinese people".

BE11:14am

China is c40-50% of group profits, Credit Suisse guesses.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

PM11:14am

Blimey

BE11:14am

Another answer is, "it's a company that flips money generated in China as fast as possible to use it for acquisitions in regulated markets, which sometimes means neighbouring areas like as TradeFX."

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And it's done okay with that. Regulated is now slightly less than half of group revenue.

BE11:15am

But of course, China's Penal Code explicitly states that gambling is prohibited and opening a gambling house, or acting as an agent to the opening of a gambling house, is a criminal act.

BE11:15am

That's why the Playtech operators work mostly (but not exclusively) via gaming licences in the Philippines.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

BE11:15am

BE11:15am

Another thing worth noting is a concentration of risk here.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Just five customers generated more than half of Playtech's 2016 gaming revenue. CS estimated that 20 per cent of gaming revenue came from a single Philippines reseller.

BE11:16am

So anyway, that's the context. But Playtech says today that it's not China that's the problem.

BE11:16am

So, given the size of the warning, it's probably Malaysia.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Playtech's second-biggest Asian end market. Though again you'll not see it on that list of licencees above.

BE11:17am

What happened here was that Malaysia dropped in a new police chief at the start of September, and he kicked off a wave of raids. As in, thousands of them.

BE11:17am

Here's an interesting quote in an interesting story: http://www.freemal...b-online-gambling/

11:17 am
BE11:17am

“We have deported 416 China nationals believed to be involved in the Macau scam syndicate, and efforts are being intensified to investigate 100 other suspects before they are deported to their countries of origin,” [Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi] said.

BE11:17am

So, let's assume Malaysia is the problem. Canaccord says ...........

BE11:17am

A four-month block to Malaysia revenues could impact group revenues by c.€14m, with a significant drop through to profits.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

.... But to reiterate, Playtech licencees don't officially operate out of Malaysia.

PM11:18am

If it was a Chinese or Malaysian company making kit that facilitated breaking the law in Britain, we'd go nuts, right?

BE11:19am

Yes, guess so. Though this is not new news in any way, I should make clear. GVC, Playtech. 888, PartyGaming .....

11:19 am
PM11:19am

sure

BE11:19am

.... all floated (or reversed in some cases) with the explicit pitch that they were operating in grey markets.

BE11:20am

For Playtech it has a huge reliance on operators out of the Philippines ... and it's not unrealistic to speculate that those operators sometimes appear to involve persons of interest to various law enforcement authorities.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Which makes the vagueness of Playtech's RNSes with relation to its Asian operations a little unhelpful, though probably necessary from a corporate point of view.

BE11:21am

In terms of the lines the analysts get to draw between Chinese revenues and whatever, they're never official guidance. It's all a bit ..... well, uninvestable for a lot of buyside, I suspect.

BE11:22am

Let's jump back to the top line though. Here's Morgan Stanley on what's happening to forecasts.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Guidance of "around 5% below the bottom end of market expectations" .....

BE11:22am

implies FY17 EBITDA of ~€325m, a 9% cut to our €355m forecast (consensus €352m) and an 11% downgrade to EPS. This would imply ~3% EBITDA growth for the company in H2. We would expect to cut our 2018 EBITDA forecast (€393m, consensus €395m) by at least this much (to ~€355m) given the rebasing and lack of clarity on the outlook.

BE11:22am

The company attributes the majority of the downgrade to "a recent slowdown in certain parts of Asia" due to recent changing market conditions. While the statement does not specify the cause, we have spoken to the company and understand this largely relates to its Asia business ex-China. Asia is c.40% of Playtech's gaming business, and we estimate China is the majority of this (around 33% of gaming revenue). It says that it had expected that activity would return to normalised levels in a relatively short timeframe, but it is now not expecting any significant improvement in 2017. The company also highlights continued challenges with the Sun Bingo contract, which may amount to ~€5m greater losses than our previous estimate of €20m of losses.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Although Asian revenue concentration is a known risk, and to some extent reflected in the significant valuation discount (60-70%) to its closest peers, this is clearly a very disappointing update, and the opacity of the situation will heighten investor concerns around the Asian business, particularly in the wake of the selldown of its founder and majority shareholder. We see Playtech as a well positioned business in a structural growth industry and our recent work detailed the sustainability of organic growth in its developed markets (which the statement says remained strong), but this will provide little comfort until greater clarity is achieved. We rate the stock Overweight with a 1400p price target.

BE11:23am

Canaccord, also buying.

BE11:24am

Playtech's shares are up by 19% in 2017, but it is still on a 2018 EV/Ebitda of 10.4x and a cash adjusted PER of 12.6x, against a peer group average of 10.7x and 15.6x. As a market-leading technology supplier into a structural growth market, we believe it merits a premium. Clearly, there will be disappointment at this update. But we would see any weakness following the trading update as a buying opportunity, and view the Capital Markets Day on November 14 as an opportunity for PTEC to demonstrate some of its technical innovations that underpin future premium growth expectations. We trim our TP from 1140p to 1090p to reflect the downgrades, putting it on an 11.5x 2018 EV/Ebitda and 14.2x cash-adjusted PER. BUY.

11:23 am
PM11:24am

(Thats a pretty heroic target price)

BE11:24am

(It is.)

undefined
11:24 am
BE11:24am

So, best just note sector peer GVC

BE11:24am

Which has ditched its poison pill, probably.

BE11:25am

As in, a poison pill that stops it eating other companies .... I'm not sure there's a word for that.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

And the response is .....

Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 133.60, up 6.5 (+5.11%), High: 135.00, Low: 127.00, Volume: 17.58m
BE11:26am

This is GVC ditching its Turkish facing operations to Ropso Malta, which is a kind of management buyout except with the IT contractors rather than the management.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Price structured to reflect the fact that Turkey could shut it down entirely this afternoon.

BE11:27am

Up to a maximum pay out of €150m over 5 years paid on
a monthly basis.

PM11:27am

ha

11:27 am
BE11:27am

That's versus c.€35m of clean EBITDA last year, so it's very nearly a giveaway.

BE11:28am

The argument from the sellside is that it's worth the dilution.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Overall, we view this as a positive move by GVC. The groups exposure to Turkey has been the only real bear point on what has been a very attractive overall investment case. We would also note that at 13% of FY17 EBITDA we believe the Turkish business is a smaller % of profits than some believed. We do not expect to make any change to FY17 expectations (clean EBITDA of €270m). In terms of FY18 we are likely to reduce FY18 EBITDA by €35m to reflect the disposal (currently €310m), we would argue that the earnings quality of the business will improve significantly and a re-rating can follow. While a short period, the trading in October again highlights that momentum in the business remains strong. We would re- iterate our BUY recommendation.

BE11:29am

And Canaccord (again).

BE11:29am

This is a materially dilutive transaction, but one which transforms the risk profile of GVC, and provides a strong signal of impending M&A activity, from a management team which has created significant shareholder value from its previous deals.
The transaction is likely to complete close to the FY17 year end, and while October trading is comfortably ahead of our Q4 assumptions, we leave our FY17 forecasts unchanged. However, for FY18, we reduce Ebitda by €34.9m from €307.9m to €273.0m, driving EPS down 14% from 74.6c to 64.5c.We downgrade FY19 EPS by 12%.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

GVC shares are up by 54% in 2017 and by 148% over two years, on a combination of material upgrades and a very significant rerating. The impact of the disposals will be for GVC's 2018 EV/Ebitda multiple to move from 10.8x to 12.3x (sub-sector average is around 11x), with the PER rising from 14.5x to 16.8x. Given underlying upgrade momentum, and optionality around M&A, alongside a significant reduction in regulatory risk, we think GVC can support a premium sector rating. We raise our TP from 925p to 1010p, putting the shares on a 13.0x FY18 EV/Ebitda. This clearly factors in some assumption of M&A activity (and this is unlikely to materialise, ahead of the outcome of the Triennial Review, likely in Q2 2018). But we view a second round of UK industry consolidation as inevitable. However, we would also flag Ladbrokes Coral (LCL-LSE : 127p | Buy, TP 165p) as a potentially cheaper way into GVC. BUY.

BE11:31am

Now of course, stopping trading in a territory where gambling is illegal doesn't erase your liability to prosecution or fines

BE11:32am

Either for wagering or for payments processing, so the Erdoğan risk is not removed entirely from the investment case.

11:32 am
GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 949.00, up 2 (+0.21%), High: 962.00, Low: 941.00, Volume: 1.60m

PM11:33am

Telit Communications PLC (TCM:LSE): Last: 164.25, down 9.25 (-5.33%), High: 174.50, Low: 162.25, Volume: 1.13m
PM11:36am

153p live

BE11:36am

I guess a question to be asked would be why it's taken so long to open the file. Or indeed why there wasn't a file already, given the stuff that's been flying about the City's backchannels on this one for about a decade.

11:36 am
undefined
BE11:37am

Okay, onto the big stuff?

BE11:37am

BT mentioned a few times. Started up, now down .....

11:37 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 256.95, down 3.55 (-1.36%), High: 267.80, Low: 253.00, Volume: 14.85m
PM11:38am

Interims here https://www.invest...1711020700043295V/

BE11:38am

The dividend guidance is ...... well, it's nuanced.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Most reports are saying it's a retention of the progressive policy and a flay payout y-o-y, which is correct but also slightly wrong.

BE11:40am

Because BT will now “maintain or grow the dividend each year whilst reflecting a number of factors including underlying medium term earnings expectations and levels of business reinvestment".

BE11:40am

That's new.

11:40 am
PM11:41am

hmm

BE11:41am

The previous progressive guidance was for DPS growth of less than 10%. No caveats.

BE11:41am

Moreover .....

11:41 am
BE11:42am

... our first priority for the allocation of free cash flow is value-
enhancing re-investment in our business to drive long-term profitable growth. This creates long-term value for our shareholders, strengthens the pension fund covenant, and supports the development of products and services our customers can value and use to grow their businesses. Cash flow after investment is available to support the pension, fund our progressive dividend and maintain a strong balance sheet

BE11:42am

You can see what happens next, right?

BE11:42am

(@GB: H1 of 4.85p, unchanged year on year.)

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Here's Jefferies, reading between the lines.

BE11:43am

Given that the incoming Chairman has been meeting with shareholders for several weeks, it seems inconceivable to us that he was not fully involved in formulating (what we believe to be) the refined policy. Cons currently models FY17/18 DPS +3% y/y (vs JEFe flat). We would expect any DPS growth expectations to be trimmed now.

BE11:44am

So anyway, in terms of the numbers we don't learn an awful lot.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Revenues slightly weaker than expected, particularly for Enterprise, but mobile and Openreach compensate.

BE11:45am

Let me grab Morgan Stanley off the conference call.

BE11:46am

BT shares have been fairly volatile today. Initially the shares appeared to have a "relief rally" with no new major bad news from the results release. However, the shares have since traded down as investors crunch over the details, especially the continued weakness in Global Services and capex plans.
The conference call is ongoing with no new commitments on the big topics, such as fibre investments, pension and football rights. BT say that fibre investments are inevitable, but the question is how fast will they ramp up and when do they start. Even though the BT share price has been weak, we feel investors are looking for reassurance on the above operational issues (as well as the dividend at the FY results), as opposed to a particular share price level at which to become more positive on the shares. We stay Equal-weight.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

And Citi.

BE11:47am

The change to the setting of the interim dividend does not ring of
confidence and neither does the ceasing of full quarterly reporting from 1Q 2018/19. Revenue that was only flat qoq in Consumer was better at EE, up at +3.8% yoy, despite the roaming drag, and postpaid ARPU rose 2%. GS likely the main concern.

PM11:47am

hmm, all that's rather unsettling

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Hang on, you want to be unsettled? Let me check of Saeed at Louis Capital has sent anything over this morning .....

PM11:48am

hahaha

BE11:48am

Yep! Sales desk view here, please note.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Go on then

BE11:48am

**** BT

P261p, PT 220p - SELL RATING - GOOD BYE DIVIDENDS - GS EBITDA -39% SIMILAR TO 2008

BE11:48am

**** On BT CC - Global services EBITDA down 39% and revenues down 10%. This is a terrible terrible set of results from a division which still represents a very large 21% of the business.

**** I know that the content business is destroying billions and there is no customer growth there but another 21% of the business at Global services is contracting at a rate of 39% at the EBITDA level which is feeding into FCF. BT thinks they are maintaining a progressive dividend - in their dreams unless it is a perpetual declining progressive dividend.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

That's one of four mails from Mr Baradar this morning, all excellent. As I've said before: do get on his list.

PM11:49am

Excellent

BE11:49am

No iffs and buts - BT is going to 220p and then lower unless they follow my five remedies:

**** IMMEDIATE ACTION IS NECESSARY TO SAVE THE COMPANY. I RECOMMEND THE FOLLOWING REMEDY:

** 1) BT parts way with Gavin Patterson asap,
** 2) stops its value destroying content investment,
** 3) cuts dividend to a sustainable 3% yield and
** 4) invests aggressively in fibre to drive future growth and
** 5) then in my view we will see a reversal in BT's fortune which on execution of the above will see the stock begin to recover again.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

And in terms of the numbers .......

BE11:51am

Numbers this morning are weak with contraction across the business but are not really important for the longer term. BT's engine of growth - the so-called TV business - has now imploded and gone into stand-still (see below). After investing billions in "uneconomical" sports content, BT this quarter is in the unenviable position to report that those billions in investment are now resulting in an irrelevant net BT TV customer additions of 7k, a growth of 0.4% on the previous quarter. THIS IS GAME OVER - they need to stop investing in "uneconomical" sports content with no prospect of return or face the fact that the next profit warning will be the least of their problems.

BE11:51am

The KPI's form the TV net adds are FRANKLY SHOCKING at a time which should be defined as a period of growth. For Q2 BT added only 7k TV customers for a total of £1,765m - the progression in the last few quarters has been 63k in Q2 16/17, 52k in Q3 16/17, 14k in Q4 and 8k in Q1 17/18 and 7k this quarter - at this rate they will soon be net losers!. BT CONTINUES TO DESTROY SHAREHOLDER VALUE by investing in +32% COST INFLATION in an environment of non-existing growth. The next impact on FCF will be BT's requirement to increase CAPEX significantly as a result of the WLA review, and the multi-billion pound value destroying EPL auctions early in 2018, with the resultant pressure on an unsustainable dividend policy (a progressive dividend policy is not sustainable, in my view - they need to cut) .

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Saeed Baradar. Louis Capital. A one-man justification for the value of Mifid II payments.

undefined
BE11:52am

Eight minutes to the start of the new era.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

What can we fill the time with?

BE11:53am

Oh, here's a good thing.

BE11:53am

Majestic Wine.

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Go on

BE11:54am

Jonathan Pritchard at Peel Hunt had a cracking note a month or so ago about how Majestic is a prime breakup/MBO candidate.

BE11:55am

Sorry! I remember, it wasn't Jonathan! It was Panmure!

11:55 am
BE11:55am

https://www.ft.com...-93c5-648314d2c72c

BE11:55am

Very, very much worth reading that.

BE11:56am

Anyway, Majestic's been in to see Peel Hunt and seem to have pitched a joined-up-business theory.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Somewhat in contrast to the Panmure argument. Here's the gist.

BE11:57am

Our meeting with Majestic management was encouraging on two counts. Naked Wines is intending to return to historic levels of
marketing spend. This is likely to boost the top line but hold
back medium-term profit growth to a degree. More importantly,
the group as a whole is facing down the industry headwinds
satisfactorily. It’s not time to call for a dramatic rerating of
Naked as it is still to fully come off the naughty step after the
direct mail error in the US. And there are still fundamental
questions to answer in the core retail business. But forecast
momentum is probably flat, not negative, and thus we are closing
our bear and moving EBIT nearer to consensus.

BE11:57am

Alongside our nerves on core retail’s profit momentum,
we were also concerned by the apparent lack of opportunities to grow the Naked Wines business. Direct mail ultimately didn’t work in the US, and management has taken a step back in marketing spend in H1 as new personnel beds in. Of course that means that profitability improves, especially as it appears that the contribution from the mature Angels has continued to grow. H1 will thus be flattered in profit terms (Naked will make a profit, not a loss this year) but of more fundamental importance is the potential for investment to recommence at Naked, especially in the US. We understand partnerships could continue to be at the core of the marketing and hope that high ROI opportunities still exist. So the meeting allayed enough of our short- and long-term fears to impel us to upgrade (by £2m on average) and, in the absence of negative forecast momentum, it’s time to go back to HOLD. Questions remain though.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

And interesting read in the context of the Panmure breakup stuff above, and I suspect that line of thought might have some legs over the longer term.

BE11:58am

(Do lines of thought have legs? You know what I mean.)

undefined
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

I guess we can tackle Shell in the one minute until BOE.

BE12:00pm

Via Citi.

BE12:00pm

Citi's Take — RDS 3Q17 earnings were 7% above Citi expectations on a CFFO basis, aided largely by stronger LNG earnings. The 9M picture is that the business has achieved a “breakeven” (coverage of capex and full dividend) of c. $55 oil, setting the stage for an end to the dilutionary scrip dividend structure when the company updates forward-guidance at the end of this month. The debate we think the market is yet to fully embrace is whether shareholders are being over-prioritised versus re-investment; we continue to think that forward growth options for RDS are still largely challenged at these oil prices.

12:00 pm
undefined
BE12:00pm

Done!

BE12:00pm

7-2.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

*BANK OF ENGLAND RAISES KEY INTEREST RATE TO 0.5%; VOTE 7-2

BE12:01pm

I think the consensus was for a 6-3 vote so, fractionally more hawkish at the margin?

BE12:02pm

GBP at $1.3129, down 0.9% from 11.59am.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

FTSE pinging higher for obvious reasons. 0.5% now.

PM12:02pm

Hmm, this new era feels rather like the old era. So far at least

BE12:03pm

Let's stay on air and reward the first economist to hit send on their analysis with some aritime.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

The winner is Paul Mumford of Cavendish Asset Management! 12:01pm!

BE12:04pm

We’ve known for some time that the zero rate era can’t go on forever. But with continued high levels of debt in the economy and business lending remaining anaemic compared to historic levels, there is a real question mark over how appropriate this rise is – and that’s not to mention the uncertainties around Brexit. Rises can harm the economy by killing off consumer spending, so it looks as if the Bank of England found itself between a rock and a hard place on this one. However some might argue that this only reverses a kneejerk “Brexit panic rise” which should never have happened in the first place.

This rise is little more than symbolic, was expected and was factored into share prices and priced into sterling in advance. What’s more likely to cause market movement will be any indications of further, more significant rises. For example, although it might seem counterintuitive, rising rates could encourage house buyers to move quickly to lock in fixed rate mortgages at current levels.

On the plus side, higher rates will be positive for cash-rich companies that are in a position to earn solid interest, and pension funds with large deficits who may be in line for a much needed boost given the impact on bond yields. Although gilts yields will be affected, minimal rises won’t bring returns anywhere near high enough to account for rising inflation – meaning equities remain the more attractive investment.

BE12:04pm

Well done, Cavendish Asset Management's Paul Mumford!

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Quick typer.

12:05 pm

BE12:06pm

Which we'll leave you to enjoy in peace. Thanks all.

12:06 pm

Goodbody:
